Thanks for the heads up.

This patch looks like more to fix than to a feature so I'm not sure why a minor version is required for this one.

Also this goes without saying that we will broke the stable branch policy that is followed by nova [1].

I've bumped the minor version just to be aligned with the Stein release [1] (19.3.0, released in July), where we decided to bump it because of this patch.

Again, don't bother with this. Own the fact that this method has side effects, like all the ones around it in the _update_to_placement flow.

Despite the fact that you're not allowed to reference the same provider more than once, we should still process this in lex order of the files, i.e. sort this by provider_file.

Or, as suggested in the previous patch, have it be an ordered list instead of a dict.

I don't really want to see this every time _update_to_placement runs. We should do some kind of 'warn once' behavior here. But carefully, allowing for providers to reappear/re-disappear on subsequent iterations...

Good point, in the previous patch it was the other way around. It doesn't matter, because the schema won't allow both to be set, but for consistency it might be better to make them match.

Does this work even with provider_id=name? and should'nt this list be empty since we are not overwriting existing rps form virt driver.

Or are we looking at rewriting changes made by the file and previous steps already check for conflicts

> Does this work even with provider_id=name?

Yes [1].

We're only allowing this to update existing providers, not create new ones [2]. But we also need to ignore specified providers that don't exist here, to account for ironic nodes that got moved to another hash ring -- and that's what the ValueError below accounts for. Might be worth a debug log at L1828: "Ignoring %(provider_id)s because it's not on this host." Or if that's too noisy, at least a comment to that effect.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/compute/provider_tree.py#L445-L446
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/612497/3/specs/train/approved/provider-config-file.rst@207

Yeah, I don't think you want to be remembering which providers you processed from one run to the next. We want to reassert the file contents if something (human via placement API, or even update_provider_tree) makes a live change to the things the file owns (e.g. removes a trait or removes/changes an inventory).
As previously mentioned, don't do this https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676522/18/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py@1834

Okay, this is going to be a bit of a ramble...

As discussed elsewhere, you shouldn't keep track of which providers you've mucked with from one iteration (i.e. RT periodic) to the next, because you need to overwrite every time, in case you're e.g. editing something update_provider_tree sets up, or "correcting" something the admin mucked with out of band via the placement API.

However, you *do* need to do the union(provider_configs) duplicate checking that picks up e.g. $name and $uuid of the same provider (which would be missed by your lower-level checks as noted elsewhere).

I was going to say you can do that check just once, on startup... but you really can't, because we need to account for entire providers appearing/disappearing in prov_tree and even placement between iterations.

So no, you actually have to do that check once per _merge_provider_configs -- but you have to do it from scratch (not remembering whatever happened on the previous iteration).

But how do we react if we detect a conflict on not-startup? We can't blow up the compute process; we either have to ignore that provider *or* use the first one (and the file ordering actually *is* important, as questioned elsewhere). The spec talks vaguely about how to react to this in terms of resource class conflicts [1], but not providers. I'm leaning toward "sorting is important, use the first one, warn like heck".

The logic also needs to account for a "duplicate" between $COMPUTE_NODE and $real_name_or_uuid. As discussed elsewhere, such a dup is arguably legit for the ironic driver, but not otherwise. Would it be too much of a hack to detect when we're using the ironic driver and special-case that? I suspect yes. But perhaps it makes sense to use the same logic of use-the-first-one -- which means an admin using the ironic driver is on the hook to make sure $real_name_or_uuid comes *first* in the processing order if that's what they meant to do. Yeah, I think that makes sense.

Whatever decisions we make for the above need to be reflected in the spec and docs.

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ussuri/approved/provider-config-file.html#provider-config-consumption-from-nova (see Provider Tree Merging)
suggest calling this something more like source_file_name and making it clear in docstrings that its only purpose is to make messages more useful.

This needs to check for the COMPUTE_NODE trait instead, which is present on compute nodes since [1].

(Even without that, this condition was too broad, as it would pick up child providers for e.g. bandwidth and VGPUs. Those should not be encompassed by $COMPUTE_NODE.)

[1] I4cb9cbe1e02c3f6c6148f73a38d10e8db7e61b1a

You could just `return` above and dedent the rest, since providers_to_update will never be empty for $COMPUTE_NODE. (That would mean the provider tree is empty, which should never happen; if it does it means we called this sucker from the wrong place.)

Should be using _warned_providers here.

But when we do, we need to be a bit clever about it. Because providers can appear and disappear (in the ironic case, for now; potentially for other cases later), I want to make sure we *also* warn if a previously-absent provider appears, and then *disappears* again later. To be clear:

- provider is absent: warn
- provider is still absent: don't warn again
- provider appears: cool, return it from here
- provider disappears: *warn again*
- provider still absent: don't warn again.

etc.

To make that happen, you'll want to *remove* it from self._warned_providers (if it was present there) when L1781 succeeds

Sorry, just noticed this is returning a list of _Provider rather than ProviderData.

(nts: which probably means the tests are missing/wrong for this case)

I think you can get away with

 [root.data() for root in ...]
would be worth a NOTE here explaining why we're doing this (i.e. so we re-warn if this provider disappears again later)

Following on from [1], I think we're missing checks for providers specified explicitly by both UUID and name in the config.

I feel like we've talked this through before, and maybe even landed on "we don't need that", but I want to go through it again to make sure.

I think there are three main cases we need to account for:
- Ironic node (root) providers. We get these for cheap via [2] because name==uuid. But these can appear/disappear from one iteration to the next.
- The (single) compute node root provider in the non-ironic case. We can't check this until runtime because there's no way to predict what name will go with what UUID. However, unlike ironic nodes and child providers (below), this is guaranteed to exist in the provider_tree by the time we get here, and it's guaranteed never to go away while we're watching.
- Non-root providers (bw, pgpu, accel). Also can't check until runtime; but these *can* appear/disappear (I think -- see comment @L1766).

Pretty sure we decided that we would detect conflicts for non-root providers at runtime, warn, and then ignore them. They should be subject to the same warn-once logic as for the no-op entries.

For non-ironic compute nodes, we want to be able to fail nova-compute startup when we find a name/uuid conflict. I think we can do this by adding a check for the COMPUTE_NODE trait. We can get away with that only because we can rely on the compute node RP not appearing and disappearing on us.

So in summary, I think we need this method to (locally) track the *UUIDs* of all providers from the config as we find them (by name *or* UUID) in the provider_tree. If we hit a dup, we check whether it's a COMPUTE_NODE. If it is, fail hard. If it isn't, warn-once. (That will mean keeping track of providers thus warned in a fashion similar to _absent_providers. You may even be able to combine into a single self._warned_providers. Not sure.)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676029/34/nova/compute/provider_config.py@218
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676029/34/nova/compute/provider_config.py@218

Do we want to allow overwriting existing inventory of a resource class from provider config or only allow adding inventories of new resource classes?
agree with both of your conclusions.

Had to remind myself via the spec: we're supposed to only allow adding inventories. We're supposed to be checking the provider tree that comes out of update_provider_tree and punting if any of the resource classes overlap with what's in the config. That's repeatable because update_provider_tree is supposed to reset each time to just the inventories the virt driver is responsible for.

And indeed, that check isn't in place yet. Needs to be added.

Not sure whether we need to be as strict about traits. I think we decided we do. At first I was going to say we should be lenient to accommodate admins adding custom traits manually; but I think we ended up deciding that we should force them to do it all one way or the other, not mix and match.
Does the ResourceTracker re-applies the config periodically? If yes, why? If no then how can this dissappearing can happen?

I'm not sure what you mean by "modify the providers descriptor".

If you want to make RDT-via-child-providers work with the current design, you're going to have to manage the creation/deletion of the child providers outside of nova, like cyborg is doing for accels. Having done that, the provider config can tweak inventories and traits -- which means your outside agent shouldn't do those things; else thrashing.

The point of this chunk of code, though, is that your outside agent can decide to add and remove the child provider on the fly, and nova-compute will handle that gracefully *without* a restart.

Not sure if this addresses your concern...

Yes, the RT loads the config once, but applies it on every iteration of update_available_resource.

Providers can disappear/reappear in a couple of cases:
- When the ironic virt driver is in play (e.g. hash ring rebalance)
- Pretty sure child providers can come and go. For example, aren't bandwidth providers managed by neutron in such a way that they can appear/disappear with a restart of neutron (but not nova-compute)? Likewise accelerators, soon.
@Eric, Does cache ways in RDT qualify as "reconfigurable" child provider? if we modify the providers descriptor would tat be captured as a change of child provider count/presence?

am kind of but it would only be updated after an agent restart.

so its static form the point of view of the resource tracker but you could modify it and then restart the compute service however if you do so you should ensure that that you dont violate any current allcoations.

Big thanks for the explanation. I missed these cases. Yes, reconfiguration and restart of neutron-agent can lead to providers appearing disappearing under the root provider. I'm glad you guys thought this through.

The single unit test in the current patch does not cover this function well enough. I see some functional tests in the next patch but I'm not sure that covers every aspect of this function either.

For example I don't see test coverage for L1745, L1757, 1771 in the this or the next patch.

I tried to add more test cases to cover exception code but it is fairly hard for me to create a test case or abnormal config to raise a ValueError exception... probably I am too naive to Python and lack of advanced unit test skills. 

I temporarily leave it be and let's do a careful code review first; meanwhile I will google for some advanced skills to do unit test.

I have three thoughts on this:
1. Under the haproxy based load balancers, we assume healthy until proven otherwise. Maybe we should artificially "ONLINE" this instead of "RESTARTING".
2. If we move forward with "RESTARTING", we need to document it and add a release note. https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/index.html#operating-status-codes
3. Is "RESTARTING" giving too much implementation specific information? Would "UPDATING" or something else be more generic for other drivers to use?

1.2. perhaps you missed that RESTARTING is an (internal) state in the amphora API, so it's not part of the Octavia public API.
When the health-manager service receives a heartbeat from an amphora, the operating status of a member in RESTARTING state is not updated (we keep the previous state) because we know that it could lead to invalid states. Its state will be updated once the amphora-agent is sure that keepalived has been correctly restarted.
3. yes, UPDATING would probably sound better than RESTARTING

doc/source/user/flavors.rst.message: just noticed this: shouldn't this go in the admin docs, since flavor setup is done by admins?

Apologies for not noting this during the spec process:

Is it possible that I want TIS, but don't care which TPM version makes it happen? If so, as currently designed, I would have to express that to placement via

 required=in:COMPUTE_SECURITY_TPM_1_2,COMPUTE_SECURITY_TPM_2_0

...but I don't think we have any way to express `in:` via extra_specs/image_meta.

So either we have to make that ^ happen, or we have to swizzle the design in some way.

The easiest thing would be to:
- Make the trait optional in extra_specs/image_meta;
- Make hw:tpm_model required if you want TPM
- Add a request filter such that, if hw:tpm_model is specified but a version trait is not, we add the appropriate `required`: for TIS, required=in:...1_2,...2_0; for CRB, required=...2_0

This also takes us further away from requiring operators to speak placement-ese in flavors, which is a good thing IMO.

I *think* this is what we landed on at the PTG:

- to get TPM, you can specify required version, or hw:tpm_model, or both:
- required=$version present, hw:tpm_model=$model present => you get $model at $version
- required=$version present, hw:tpm_model absent => TIM at $version
- required=$version absent, hw:tpm_model=$model present => request filter adds required=$version, where $version = 2_0 if $model is CRB else 1_2
- required=1_2, hw_tpm_model=CRB => request filter errors.

Please confirm.

[Much later] This doesn't make sense in light of the defaults folks would be expecting if they're familiar with the libvirt side of things (and if they're not, they won't care). The way this should work is:

- You have to specify a version. This is how you request the feature. Because the versions are like different things; it's not like 2.0 is a superset of 1.2. So you want the version you want, and you don't want the other one.
- The model defaults to TIS. You have to say CRB if you want CRB; and if you want CRB, you have to have said 2.0.

oslo_cache/tests/functional/dogpile_cach.message:
I wonder if we test the right things here.

By looking more deeply to these changes, I think we have some mistakes here and I think we need more work here.

bmemcached was introduced to allow us to use SASL with memcache and especially with our memcache_pool backend (which is the one that use memcached) (c.f I40b9f4eac518f34a3dfb710b5c4ab3a76da7c00c).

Here, by doing this (`backend="dogpile.cache.bmemcached"`) we will test bmemcached with dogpile and we will not test our memcache_pool backend.

IMO Functional tests should testing our drivers, and our backends only.

To implement the right test I think we should use something like this:

```
backend="oslo_cache.memcache_pool"
memcache_sasl_enabled=True
memcache_username=something
memcache_password=*****
```

This is basically the point of the whole exercise. This feature will ensure that the traits in the file get set on the provider, regardless of what came from elsewhere. If you try to manually remove such a trait from the provider, the resource tracker will put it back on the next periodic.

Likewise: we're only positively asserting inventories, not allowing removal of any. In this case, since it's inventory, it's more than just binary -- which again is the point of the exercise: to override anything set from elsewhere, including by the driver. If there's an inventory that's already on the provider, we'll overwrite it with whatever values come from the file. And this allows us to use the same logic to account for a) inventories set up by the compute driver and b) inventories we set via this file on the last periodic: we just replace in either case.

I think this also shows a weakness of the chosen validation strategy. With the current architecture we will need multiple levels of validation code.
1) schema validation to enforce syntax
2) validate basic semantic like pure uuid or name collision (like in this patch)
3) later we need to resolve $COMPUTE_NODE to uuid and RP name to uuid THEN do another level of semantic validation to see if a single RP is not mentioned more than once.

I think after #1) we should load everything as is, then resolve every possible ambiguity of identification and then do the semantic validation in a single run. I think this will lead to a less fragmented validation logic and it allow us to emit better error messages.

We've struggled with this over several iterations.

This check, at load time, is designed to make sure you never specify the same actual identifier (including the special $COMPUTE_NODE value) twice. Then later, at runtime, we decide whether to use the explicit entry or the $COMPUTE_NODE entry to apply to a given provider.

Because it was going to be really hard to do otherwise, we decided to take advantage of the fact that the RP name and UUID are the same for ironic nodes, which this bit will also catch.

So then we would just have to worry about a (non ironic node) provider being specified by both name and ID. That's something we also can't detect until runtime. So that check should go in the subsequent patch.

76e651005b [1] introduced a new feature on stable, this is something that we try to avoid especially on projects that follow the stable branches policy [2], however these changes seems to fix a bug [3] and the option have a default value so I think we can continue with this backport even if you follow the stable policy [2], a release note is associated so these changes are visible from a customer POV.

However if we decide to continue with that I prefer release a minor version to notify users that a feature have been embded.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/76e651005b62888090dfe097b7fe03c62cdd32f1
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/stable_follows-policy.html
[3] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1883712

Yes, my original backport comment (in ussuri) was:
"New config option with changed default value, but it has release notes and default aims for a better experience (not loosing some notifications thanks to enabled retry)"
It is more a bugfix on existing feature (nova-neutron communication) than new feature so was deemed good to go in stable branches.
That said, no objection on minor version bump here for that reason!

Indeed it's not ideal. I was speaking with Daniel and I have an idea that goes like:

Right now we have two lists, the one that you linked that contains all extensions and another with all extensions supported by ML2/OVN.

What I could do is an intersection on these lists and in here we try to enable everything that is in the first list minus what is not supported by OVN (based on the second list) and log a message with the extensions being disabled telling why it has been disabled.

That way if a custom job wants to have a smaller list of extensions in it's job definition, the devstack module will try to enable only those instead of everything that is suported by OVN.

Let's illustrate a case here:
1. one router is processed once with 10 floating IPs.
2. a new floating IPs is added to the router.
3. Router update notification is just arrived.

neutron/agent/l3/agent.py.message:
I'm partially OK with this change. But this code was added in case the router was being initialized. If the router is in the initializing process and there is not RPC reply, the router is deleted. IMO, we should still handle this case.


[1]https://review.opendev.org/#/c/516322/

Sorry, I'm a bit confused about the cases you mentioned. IMO, you mentioned two cases:
1. If router is not in cache, aka it is trying to be added to agent for the first time. This patch should be fine, because router info was not retrieved successfully.
2. If router is in cache and processed once before, it should be run as it is. Agent must not direct remove it here. Yes, this is the bug, and this patch is mainly to fix this issue.

So make sense?

I see that you want to address the case when the MQ is down and [1] is called.

Only when the router is created the cache is updated. As you said, we are safe on this.

I don't want to block this patch, by no means. I'm just trying to find any path were a router should be deleted by this line here.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/l3/agent.py#L710

> So it took me a minute to figure out why I added this, but it was
 > basically to cover the case where the message had been in the queue
 > so long that we had decided to give-up on the action, so felt the
 > safest thing was just to remove the router since it probably isn't
 > initialized correctly.  For example, we don't know what operation
 > is failing, so assume it's broken and remove it.
 > 
 > Maybe that was an aggressive decision, but seemed correct to not
 > have a router namespace where we didn't know it it's state so
 > couldn't assume it was functional.
 > 

And you have no way to verify if it is running well or it is initialized correctly. So directly assuming it is not initialized, IMHO, looks not a good way to deal with such situation. At least, left it running as it is, should be safer than directly remove it.

 > Is there a case where we still want to remove this router?  For
 > example, on an Add but not on an Update?  I know those queue
 > actions are the same, so would need more thought than just removing
 > this code.

From the code search [1], I may say we should not remove the router on every branch.

Deleting a router should be considered very carefully, this code removal has no harm to running status of agent routers. On the contrary, remove a router has bad effect to existing resources.

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=_resync_router&i=nope&files=&repos=openstack/neutron

So it took me a minute to figure out why I added this, but it was basically to cover the case where the message had been in the queue so long that we had decided to give-up on the action, so felt the safest thing was just to remove the router since it probably isn't initialized correctly.  For example, we don't know what operation is failing, so assume it's broken and remove it.

Maybe that was an aggressive decision, but seemed correct to not have a router namespace where we didn't know it it's state so couldn't assume it was functional.

Is there a case where we still want to remove this router?  For example, on an Add but not on an Update?  I know those queue actions are the same, so would need more thought than just removing this code.

nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions.message: I've never used backticks in SQL before. Are we sure those are the right type of quotes to use?

L1523 implies that we only do this for mysql, so I think this is safe based on your googling (not that I really doubted it, hence the +2).

I wonder if maybe database names with dashes are more problematic in general and we shouldn't be allowing them on principle or something? But anyway, I'm sure we should just merge this.

Oh, derp. I didn't notice this block is MySQL only.

I agree this should then be OK based on what I found.

According to stackoverflow [1], backticks are a MySQL-only thing [2] for quoting identifiers.

They say in order to support other brands of DBMS, standard double quotes are more appropriate, though to do this in MySQL you need to SET sql_mode = 'ANSI_QUOTES'; [3] first.

Do we still support other DBMS like PostgreSQL or others? If so, it sounds like we should use the double quotes and enable the ANSI_QUOTES mode for MySQL.

[1] https://dba.stackexchange.com/questions/23129/benefits-of-using-backtick-in-mysql-queries
[2] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/identifiers.html
[3] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/sql-mode.html#sqlmode_ansi_quotes

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message: This fixes the issue with a DNS name like "starwars.", but what if there's something like starwars.deathstar.com -- should we accept that? If so, I think with this fix it would become starwars.deathstarcom, which isn't what they want. I think we need to find a way to check if the DNS domain ends in a period, and if so, just remove that last one.

rstrip('.') only removes a trailing '.' from the string if there is one present. If there is no trailing '.' in the string it will keep the string as it is.
So if the string is something like 'starwars.deathstar.com' it will return the same string with rstrip('.')

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Took me a while to figure out how we were actually deleting the delta. Turns out we create a temporary directory and clean that up after. How about this:

  When creating a live snapshot of an instance, nova creates a
  copy of the instance disk using a QEMU shallow rebase. This
  copy - the delta file - is then extracted and uploaded. The
  delta file will eventually be deleted, when the temporary
  working directory nova is using for the live snapshot is
  discarded, however, until this happens, we will use 3x the
  size of the image of host disk space: the original disk,
  the delta file, and the extracted file. This can be problematic
  when concurrent snapshots of multiple instances are requested
  at once.

  The solution is simple: delete the delta file after it has
  been extracted and is no longer necessary.

If your variable may contain special character(s) you should add double quotes around it. Password is a good example.

> I missed Bart's comment.
 > 
 > If your variable may contain special character(s) you should add
 > double quotes around it. Password is a good example.

Bart is asking if we need to add quotes around every variables in this template. What do you think?

I would not add quotes around every variable. For instance, integer values would be interpreted as string which will require you to use integer filter if you reference the variable in the playbook.

Regarding this particular template, you can add quotes around password and user unless armada service rejects user ids containing special characters.

glance/api/v2/images.py.message: We might get exception.InvalidTaskStatusTransition thrown at us here if the current status at this point of time is either "failure" or "success".

Ah, right, so if we got to one of those terminal states but didn't drop our lock, it's probably that actually did finish and failed to drop it for some error case reason. So, can I just ignore (but log) that failure here?
That or another is racing with us to it. So we probably blow up here before hitting the L 114

I guess "processing" is not a task state (correct me if I am wrong) it is running instead.

Now consider task state is "pending" i.e. taskflow is build lock is acquired and something went wrong and that task never go in running state, then with this condition it will never release lock for that image without admin intervention?

Same thing might happen with reverted state?

> What comes to the pending, it was my concern when we were talking
 > about this with Abhishek last week. The time_to_live only applies
 > to the task (and thus gets cleaned up) [1] once it hits either
 > "success" or "failure" so pending will leave it locked until manual
 > action is taken.

Ack. Can we maybe have a longer timeout for the bust-on-pending case then?

I think it's "processing":
 https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/api/v2/tasks.py#L172

But yeah, if it's stuck in pending state I don't break the lock. I thought we discussed here:

 https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/glance-import-locking

...that we would only bust the lock on "processing" state (and success/fail are obvious). I think the reason to avoid busting pending is that the task can't be heartbeating if it's not yet running. That may be because we failed to start the task at all, or because it's queued (either blocked from running due to resources, or in some future where there's actually a queue) and it's going to start. I suppose that with the obsessive task lock checking in the import flow, maybe we could enable busting in 'pending' here and the task would abort super quick if it started running after the lock got busted.

I dunno, I felt like if we're not starting tasks we're probably broken for other reasons and I wanted to be very specific about the cases when and where the lock busting happens.

If the task is stuck in pending due to some really bad failure, the task will eventually be culled by the cleanup I assume and thus will become unlocked at some point? Or does that never happen for tasks in that state?

Anyway, I dunno, maybe we get some input from others?

I guess it would have been too much to expect that we would have actually used the same states for the tasks as taskflow does [0] :(

What comes to the pending, it was my concern when we were talking about this with Abhishek last week. The time_to_live only applies to the task (and thus gets cleaned up) [1] once it hits either "success" or "failure" so pending will leave it locked until manual action is taken. 

[0] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/domain/__init__.py#L353-L404
[1] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/domain/__init__.py#L373-L375
Sounds good to me. With normal eventlet running case something should be wrong if this happens but handful of threads with uwsgi might cause us sitting in pending for a while.

Am I missing something or is this warning not warranted? Isn't this what would be locked if we get multiple concurrent requests for copy-image and the processing just haven't started yet even if it's freshly new. Like for those 200 concurrent requests nova would be sending.

Yes, you'd hit this in the race case. I had this here so I could see something happen when I poked it from a test, and I've been trying to log *lots* of information around this. Warning is probably too strong though; do you want no logging in this case or info/debug?
debug would be fine. Just don't want to flood the logs in production with something that is absolute noop for admin and likely to occur.
we also need to block this property during image-update and should not show it to end user right?

Yes, we do need to block it from update. Personally, I'd like to see it exposed to the user because it gives them a pointer to be able to go look at the task. Since the task gives granular information about progress now, it seems like it would be good to just expose it.

glance/async_/flows/api_image_import.py.message:
I got the basic idea why this class is added so that we can avoid writing same code in all the reverts of each task including internal plugins but,

IMO this is something which is breaking basic idea of taskflow. AFAIK, task should revert only those changes which were performed by the task.

> I got the basic idea why this class is added so that we can avoid
 > writing same code in all the reverts of each task including
 > internal plugins but,

That's not really the reason. We wouldn't want to put this code in the revert of every task because we just want this to run once and always at the end of revert without fail, right?

 > IMO this is something which is breaking basic idea of taskflow.
 > AFAIK, task should revert only those changes which were performed
 > by the task.

I know that's the ideal, but since nothing in the flow grabbed the lock, there is no place to mirror that in the removal during a revert. I certainly don't think we should avoid having a consistent API or a race-free import thread because of an ideal design goal like this.

The alternative would be to let the flow do the locking and block the API from returning until it got a report from the thread that it was successful or not in grabbing the lock. I could certainly do that, but it seems crazily over-complicated just to avoid having a task that only does a revert on cleanup. Is that really worth it?

What if we made the execute() of this task just *confirm* the lock that the API grabbed for us? Would that make this more balanced and alleviate that concern?
should we combine this in one function unless _asser_task_lock is used somewhere else? and if it is should we atleast change the name as it seems same.
The inner is used on L104 above, since we're already fetching the image in that case.
We likely won't ever get here in such case. If the Transition fails on line 611, it will also fail on line 625 which is not caught and either case will trigger the whole flow being reverted.

No, so that's what makes splitting thigs into bunch of internal functions hard to follow. So on L 649 you call the _finish_task, which will likely fail on L 611 and then trigger revert failing on line 625 so _drop_lock will never be called in the case we're hitting the race that would cause this NotFound. If someone else tried to bust the lock in between _finish_task and _drop_lock, they should have get caught on bustable state at that point.

So unless I missed something there literally should not be way to hit this piece of code ever in any other way than mocking the behaviour to the state that would never happen in reality.

> Here's the real-world scenario where this can happen:
 > 
 > 1. We call task.succeed() on L611, which actually happens
 > 2. While waiting for the database call to return we switch to
 > another local thread (green or not)
 > 3. That thread looks up the task, finds that its lock is bustable,
 > busts it, and grabs the lock itself

But how does it get the task in a state that is bustable. If we succeed on the succeed() call, we already have the update queued in DB, when we query that same row after, we will get the updated value, no? So we should not get bustable state in locking code. If the lock busting happens first, then we're on the same situation opposite way around the task.succeed() call will fail, we catch that, we try to call taks.fail() which will also fail and we jump into revert with never reaching the code that was supposed to prevent reverting at this point anymore.

 > 4. We get scheduled because our call has returned and move on to
 > drop_lock_for_task(), which does not find our lock.
 > 
 > It's really not related to splitting things into a bunch of
 > functions, it's just that in a distributed system you can't rely on
 > everything being atomic and orderly. This scenario could have
 > happened in the case where we grab the lock as the first task in
 > the flow too.

Yes only thing I was referring to around splitting the code was as a human it's not easy to follow what happens when you need to bounce around. Not that it actually affects the execution itself.

Now this whole situation also requires that our execution is scheduled to other thread long enough that getting over _SaveImage (which is either no-op or single query) has taken more time than our timeout and we expect the other thread not being impacted by that.

My whole point is that timing wise, _taken_ that all these things happens, we're much more likely to hit InvalidTaskStateTransition in the _finish_task and not address that and go to revert than catching up here which specifically states on the comment that it prevents us reverting if we already got this far. I wasn't saying logging it here is necessary bad thing, but not catching the condition already in _finish_task() is and likely prevents us ever getting here.

> > Here's the real-world scenario where this can happen:
 > >
 > > 1. We call task.succeed() on L611, which actually happens
 > > 2. While waiting for the database call to return we switch to
 > > another local thread (green or not)
 > > 3. That thread looks up the task, finds that its lock is
 > bustable,
 > > busts it, and grabs the lock itself
 > 
 > But how does it get the task in a state that is bustable. If we
 > succeed on the succeed() call, we already have the update queued in
 > DB, when we query that same row after, we will get the updated
 > value, no?

You mean the other thread reads the task state and sees 'success' right? It surely will, but the lock will still be set in image.os_glance_import_task, which means that thread is still going to check it for bust-ability. If suitable delay happens between step 2 and 3, the lock could be bustable by the time step 3 happens. When we finally get to run our step 4, we will fail to delete our lock from the instance, because it is gone.

My point was that you've got multiple steps here: Marking the task as success and dropping the lock from the image. Those don't happen atomically, which means at any point some other thread can see the task marked as success but the image still locked, and that lock will be bustable if the delay between marking the task as success (the last update to the task's updated_at) and the dropping of our lock here is long enough.

 > So we should not get bustable state in locking code. If
 > the lock busting happens first, then we're on the same situation
 > opposite way around the task.succeed() call will fail, we catch
 > that, we try to call taks.fail() which will also fail and we jump
 > into revert with never reaching the code that was supposed to
 > prevent reverting at this point anymore.

 > My whole point is that timing wise, _taken_ that all these things
 > happens, we're much more likely to hit InvalidTaskStateTransition
 > in the _finish_task and not address that and go to revert than
 > catching up here which specifically states on the comment that it
 > prevents us reverting if we already got this far. I wasn't saying
 > logging it here is necessary bad thing, but not catching the
 > condition already in _finish_task() is and likely prevents us ever
 > getting here.

If we fail to mark the task as successful, then we *should* call the revert path, right? If task.succeed() fails, we'll enter the exception handler, task.fail() will fail as well, which means our revert will be called, which doesn't do anything, but will chain backwards to the revert()s of previous steps in the flow. Isn't that desired?

Or are you saying that we should just not fail the flow if task.succeed() fails because we've made it this far? That doesn't seem like a good plan since the task will be exposed publicly as "this thing failed" and yet, the work of the task was not reverted.

Here's the real-world scenario where this can happen:

 1. We call task.succeed() on L611, which actually happens
 2. While waiting for the database call to return we switch to another local thread (green or not)
 3. That thread looks up the task, finds that its lock is bustable, busts it, and grabs the lock itself
 4. We get scheduled because our call has returned and move on to drop_lock_for_task(), which does not find our lock.

It's really not related to splitting things into a bunch of functions, it's just that in a distributed system you can't rely on everything being atomic and orderly. This scenario could have happened in the case where we grab the lock as the first task in the flow too.

AFAICT, there isn't any DB-specific atomicity around the task state transitions, so I think that we could race between completing the task and trying to drop the lock here right? Are you saying that can't happen for some reason, or that it's really unlikely? If the latter, I agree, but I wanted to log the case if we ever hit it. Is there some reason we should not do that?
should we add debug message here in else: saying Lock has been released or something like that?
In the non-failure case you mean? We certainly can, but we already LOG.info() right after this that the task is completed. I doubt an operator is going to know (or need to know) the difference.

nova/virt/libvirt/migration.py.message:
Assuming a future in which we support other realtime schedulers than 'fifo', I would assume those would be settable via flavor extra specs (and maybe image properties?), and not on a per-host config basis, so in a live-migration context it would not be expected to change. Therefore, we could pull the scheduler out of the vcpusched elems we're remove()ing here, stash it, and re-set it on L136.

We've had a long philosophical discussion about this on IRC. There's general agreement that "Nova is authoritative, XML isn't", so we shouldn't be "reading" information from the XML and thus treating is as authoritative... except Nova wrote the XML, so maybe it's OK? And there's definitely precedent, look up on L91, or down on L162, or L183 etc etc.

There's also general agreement that this change is "fairly trivial, consistent and would always be correct, even it was slightly overengineered" - but my beef is with the last part: I wouldn't use the word "slightly" :)

I think in the current context, it's premature and wasteful to add a field to an object that transits many times over the wire just to stash a realtime scheduler value that we can easily get through other means.
